Name: Linear Programming (LP)
Description: A method for achieving the best outcome in a mathematical model whose requirements are represented by linear relationships.
Example: Pixie Project: maximizing profit given resource constraints

Name: Nonlinear Programming (NLP)
Description: Optimization problems where some of the constraints or the objective function are nonlinear.
Appearances: Design optimization for systems with nonlinear dynamics

Name: Quadratic Programming (QP)
Description: A special type of mathematical optimization problem where the objective function is quadratic and the constraints are linear.
Solvability: Convex quadratic solvable in polynomial time

Name: Combinatorial Optimization
Description: Optimization problems where the set of feasible solutions is discrete or can be reduced to a finite one.

Name: Integer Programming (IP)
Description: Involves linear programming with the additional constraint that some or all of the variables are integers.

Name: Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP)
Description: A combination of linear programming and integer programming where some variables can be non-integer while others must be integer.
Example: Supply chain optimization with discrete decisions

Name: Convex Optimization
Description: Optimization problems where the objective function is convex and the feasible region is a convex set.

Name: Stochastic Programming (SP)
Description: Optimization models that incorporate uncertainty by considering multiple scenarios or probabilistic constraints.
Appearances: Used in finance and operations research

Name: Nash Equilibrium Optimization
Description: Finding equilibrium strategies in games where players are optimizing their own objectives.

Name: Bilevel Programming (BP)
Description: Optimization problems with two levels of decision-making
Solvability: where the constraints of one level depend on the solution to another.
Appearances: Supply chain management with hierarchical decisions
column8: Rare but critical in specific domains
